questions.question: ……………….. Rahul, it is a nice film.
questions.description: According to Rahul means ‘if what Rahul says is true.’

questions.question: Let’s swim ……………… the river.
questions.description: We use across to talk about movement in water.

questions.question: She arrived ………………. after breakfast.
questions.description: Right can mean just or exactly. Rightly means correctly.

questions.question: Peter isn’t here. John isn’t here ………………..
questions.description: After mentioning a negative idea or fact we can add another negative point by using ‘not…either’.

questions.question: It is important that he ………………. told.
questions.description: Both structures are possible. In American English the structure without ‘should’ is preferred.

questions.question: …………….. having worked hard, she failed the exam.
questions.description: Before a noun or an ing form we use in spite of. Although and even though are conjunctions used to connect clauses.

questions.question: I’m anxious …………….. my brother.
questions.description: Certain adjectives which describe people’s reactions and feelings are often followed by a to-infinitive. Anxious is one of them.

questions.question: I ……………… somebody coming.
questions.description: To say that we hear something at the moment of speaking we use ‘can hear’.

questions.question: I had hardly closed my eyes …………….. the telephone rang.
questions.description: Both when and before are possible here.

questions.question: I had no sooner closed the door .....................… somebody knocked.
questions.description: Sooner is a comparative form. We use ‘than’ after it.

questions.question: No sooner ……………….. to marry him than she started to have terrible doubts.
